L1_summary_of_paper: The paper develops a formal model to explain when and why industry leaders in hypercompetitive environments rationally choose to renew advantages more slowly (longer development time) despite faster erosion of rents, thereby increasing the probability of displacement—"self-displacement." Two industry-level forces drive hypercompetition: imitation (exponential decay of abnormal returns at rate δ) and innovation (Poisson arrival at rate λ that instantaneously displaces the leader). The leader chooses the development time T of the next advantage to maximize the present value of expected revenues net of convex time-compression costs derived from resource-accumulation microfoundations; revenues before and after launch decay with δ and are truncated by λ. Across four environment types—stable, imitative, innovative, and dual hypercompetition—the model yields comparative statics: (i) in stable settings, accelerate when the new advantage has higher market value, lower complexity, lower discount rate, and higher speed capability; (ii) with imitative hypercompetition, accelerate if the new advantage has low relative market value (versus the existing one) but decelerate if its relative market value is high; imitation lags push toward further deceleration; (iii) with innovative hypercompetition, leaders often optimally renew more slowly, accepting higher displacement risk (self-displacement), because acceleration buys little expected revenue but raises costs; and (iv) under dual hypercompetition, a rule of thumb is to accelerate only advantages with high competitive value but low market value and otherwise avoid costly time compression. The contribution integrates industry macrodynamics (δ, λ) with firm microdynamics (time-compression diseconomies) to overturn the simple "go faster" prescription and introduces self-displacement as a rational, profit-maximizing mechanism for leader turnover.

F2_risk_of_bias_notes: Results hinge on specific functional forms (exponential decay, Poisson innovation, convex acceleration costs) and calibration to stylized facts; no empirical identification or external validation within the paper.
G1_construct_mapping_note: Map δ to rivalry-driven erosion (persistence decay); λ to exogenous innovation hazard; T to speed/timing decision; forgone-revenue integral to cannibalization; displacement probability 1−e^{−λT} as leadership turnover risk; convex cost links time compression to resource-accumulation microfoundations.
G4_unifying_props_drafts: Increases in hypercompetition (δ, λ) do not monotonically imply faster renewal; the optimal speed is conditional on relative market value and cost convexity.
Self-displacement emerges endogenously when acceleration yields little expected revenue but large cost hikes under high λ.
Bridging macro erosion/innovation with micro time-compression costs overturns the naive ‘always speed up’ prescription.
NA_reason_if_any: Formal analytical model with numerical comparative statics; no empirical dataset.
I1_mechanism_statements: Higher imitation rate (δ) simultaneously depresses current rents (pushing to accelerate) and future rents from the new advantage (pushing to decelerate); the net effect depends on the new advantage’s relative market value.

Higher innovation hazard (λ) truncates future rents regardless of speed, so acceleration often fails to pay back convex costs, yielding optimal deceleration and higher displacement probability (self-displacement).
Imitation lags (θ) create a window to harvest existing rents, shifting the optimum toward slower renewal and less cannibalization.
Greater speed capability (d) or lower complexity (K) flattens acceleration costs, making acceleration more attractive ceteris paribus.

I3_theoretical_propositions: In stable environments, the leader accelerates renewal when the new advantage has higher market value, lower complexity, lower discount rate, and higher speed capability.
With imitative hypercompetition, the leader accelerates if the new advantage has low relative market value but decelerates if the relative market value is high.
Imitation lags push the leader toward slower renewal and less cannibalization of the existing advantage.
With innovative hypercompetition, higher innovation hazard generally shifts the optimum toward slower renewal and higher displacement probability (self-displacement).
Under dual hypercompetition, accelerate only advantages with high competitive value but low market value; otherwise avoid costly time compression.
J1_main_findings_summary: Speed is not universally optimal under hypercompetition; optimal renewal can be slower as δ and especially λ rise.
Self-displacement is a rational, profit-maximizing outcome when acceleration costs are convex and innovation hazard truncates rents.
Imitative hypercompetition yields opposite timing prescriptions depending on the new advantage’s relative market value.
Imitation lags create harvest windows that shift firms toward slower renewal and lower cannibalization.
A practical rule in dual hypercompetition is to accelerate only high competitive–low market value advantages.

K1_contribution_summary: By unifying industry-level erosion/innovation with firm-level time-compression costs in a formal model, the paper reframes hypercompetition: leaders often maximize value by renewing more slowly, accepting higher displacement (self-displacement). This conditional, microfounded logic overturns the simple ‘faster is always better’ view and provides testable propositions about timing, cannibalization, and leadership turnover.
